titleStmt.title: The endothelium in hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction

affiliation.orgName: Keenan Research Centre for Biomedical Science

analytic.title: The endothelium in hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction

biblStruct.note: Submitted 9 February 2017; accepted in final form 16 August 2017

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Grimmer B, Kuebler WM.
The endothelium in hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction.
First published August 31, 2017; doi:10.1152/japplphysiol.00120.2017.-Hypoxic

pulmonary vasoconstriction (HPV) in combination with hypercapnic pulmonary vasoconstriction redistributes pulmonary blood flow from poorly aerated to better ventilated lung regions by an active process of local vasoconstriction.
Impairment of HPV results in ventilationperfusion mismatch and is commonly associated with various lung diseases including pneumonia, sepsis, or cystic fibrosis.

Although several regulatory pathways have been identified, considerable knowledge gaps persist, and a unifying concept of the signaling pathways that underlie HPV and their impairment in lung diseases has not yet emerged.
In the past, conceptual models of HPV have focused on pulmonary arterial smooth muscle cells (PASMC) acting as sensor and effector of hypoxia in the pulmonary vasculature.
In contrast, the endothelium was considered a modulating bystander in this scenario.
For an ideal design, however, the oxygen sensor in HPV should be located in the region of gas exchange, i.e., in the alveolar capillary network.

This concept requires the retrograde propagation of the hypoxic signal along the endothelial layer of the vascular wall and subsequent contraction of PASMC in upstream arterioles that is elicited via temporospatially tightly controlled endothelial-smooth muscle cell crosstalk.

The present review summarizes recent work that provides proof-of-principle for the existence and functional relevance of such signaling pathway in HPV that involves important roles for connexin 40, epoxyeicosatrienoic acids, sphingolipids, and cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator.

Of translational relevance, implication of these molecules provides for novel mechanistic explanations for impaired ventilation/ perfusion matching in patients with pneumonia, sepsis, cystic fibrosis, and presumably various other lung diseases.

hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction; endothelium; conducted response; epoxyeicosatrienoic acids; cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator HYPOXIC pulmonary vasoconstriction (HPV) constitutes a fundamental and unique physiological response of the pulmonary vasculature first described by Beutner in 1852 in a feline preparation as a rise in pulmonary arterial pressure when ventilation was stopped, and a subsequent fall in pressure when ventilation was resumed (7).

The physiological relevance of the HPV response, however, was only recognized by the Swedish pharmacologists Ulf von Euler and Göran Liljestrand in their landmark paper in 1946, demonstrating that HPV serves to optimize gas exchange in inhomogeneously ventilated lungs by directing blood flow away from poorly aerated to well ventilated areas (100).

Apart from its unquestionable key physiological relevance, HPV is also of pathophysiological interest as both local or systemic infections and/or inflamma-tory disorders impair HPV, resulting in clinically relevant ventilation/perfusion (V ˙A/Q ˙) mismatching and hypoxemia in the already vulnerable group of critically ill patients with sepsis or pneumonia (64,80).

It should thus not come as a surprise that since its first description, an unebbing flow of scientists have strived to decipher the cellular mechanisms that underlie hypoxia sensing and the subsequent initiation of a vasoconstrictive response.

Over the past decade, work from various laboratories identified hypoxia-induced changes in the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in pulmonary arterial smooth muscle cells (PASMC) as a critical initial oxygen sensing event; however, the site [mitochondrial respiratory chain vs. NAD(P)H oxidase] and nature (increase vs. decrease) of these redox changes remains a matter of controversy that has been reviewed in detail elsewhere (90).

Signaling events downstream of the initial redox changes involve inhibition of oxygen-sensitive potassium channels (voltage-gated K v and TASK-1), activation of Ca 2ϩ channels (voltage-gated Ca 2ϩ channels, transient receptor potential Ca 2ϩ channels), as well as activation of the RhoA/Rho-kinase pathway, all of which have been reviewed expertly before (91).

Importantly, all these mechanistic models focus on the pulmonary arterial smooth muscle cell (PASMC) as both the sensor and effector of HPV; that is, oxygen sensing, the transduction of this signal, and the final output of smooth muscle contraction are all held within the PASMC (33).
The role of the lung endothelium in the hypoxia-induced signaling cascade that mediates HPV was, on the other hand, long assumed to be largely insignificant.
In the present review, we will set out to challenge this PASMC-centric view of HPV and highlight the emerging role of the endothelium in oxygen sensing and the triggering of PASMC contraction.

Intriguingly, the implication of the endothelium in the HPV response provides for new mechanistic concepts that may, for the first time, explain the impairment of HPV and V ˙A/Q ˙matching in patients suffering from cystic fibrosis, sepsis, or pneumonia.

div.head: The Endothelium in Hypoxic Pulmonary Vasoconstriction

p.s: The notion that the pulmonary endothelium plays at best a modulatory role in HPV is primarily based on two observations: First, isolated PASMC in vitro are fully capable to contract when exposed to hypoxia independent of the presence of an endothelium (61).

Even more, the time course of this constrictive response mirrors the characteristic temporal profile of the initial pulmonary artery pressure response in the isolated lung preparation, in that it reaches a maximum within the first 5 min that is followed by a subsequent decline (Fig. 1).
Second, the acute HPV response is unabated by endothelial denudation in isolated pulmonary arterial rings.

Unquestionably, analyses in cultured PASMCs and pulmonary arterial rings have markedly advanced our understanding of the cellular mechanisms by which smooth muscle cells sense hypoxia; yet, they notably do not reproduce the intricate anatomical characteristics of the intact organ or organism, respectively, that are critical for the design of "a good lung" (103).

Within the complex structure of the intact lung, the sensor for the alveolar oxygen partial pressure must be positioned either in the airways, the area of gas exchange, or downstream thereof in the draining pulmonary venules and veins.

At the vascular level, the area of gas exchange is thereby not limited to the alveolar capillaries, but, as we will discuss below, also comprises small, precapillary arterioles and may, according to early studies by Jameson (48) using wedged pulmonary artery catheters with a platinum electrode tip during single breath inhalations of H 2 and O 2 in patients undergoing cardiac catheterization, extend as far upstream as to pulmonary arteries 2 mm in diameter.

Further and above that, even systemic hypoxemia may elicit HPV responses as the bronchial circulation supplies vasa vasorum to the walls of all but the smallest pulmonary arteries in larger mammals (62).

With respect to the position of the effector, i.e., the actual site of vasoconstriction, a large body of functional and anatomical studies indicate that HPV occurs throughout the pulmonary vascular bed, including the microvascular region con-Fig.
1. Contraction of pulmonary artery smooth muscle cells in response to hypoxia.

Representative images show human pulmonary artery smooth muscle cells (PASMC) imaged under a wide-field, live-cell microscope at normoxia (21% O2, t ϭ 0 min) and for 10 min after a rapid switch to hypoxic (1% O2) conditions.
Notably, the extent of the constrictive response to hypoxia is quite variable between smooth muscle cells.
The top row shows a smooth muscle cell with a profound constrictive response to hypoxia, whereas in the bottom row another cell with a moderate response from the same experiment is depicted.
Quantitative analysis of PASMC length yields the time course of contraction that corresponds to the temporal profile of the acute hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction (HPV) response in intact lungs.
*P Ͻ 0.05 vs. t ϭ 0 min (normoxia).
taining nonmuscular arterioles, capillaries, and venules (91).

The latter phenomenon is likely attributable to the ability of pulmonary arterial endothelial cells to constrict per se under hypoxic conditions via a mechanism that involves the release of zinc and a subsequent zinc-induced inhibition of myosin light chain phosphatase (6).

The largest and most consistent HPV responses, however, occur in small pulmonary arteries and arterioles Ͼ 50 m, respectively (91), as indicated by the findings 1) that pulmonary microvessels with diameters of Ͻ 100 m only have scattered smooth muscle cells instead of a complete smooth muscle layer in the media (51,66); 2) that the smallest blood vessels that, if occluded, cause an increase in alveolar dead space are in the range of 100 -150 m (109); and 3) that direct intravital microscopic observation of the pulmonary vasoconstrictive response to hypoxia in intact mice did not detect any change in vascular diameter in arterioles of Ͻ30 m in diameter, while arterioles 30 -50 m in diameter responded to a decrease in inspired oxygen from 21% to 11% with a diameter change of ~7% (94).

According to Poiseuille's law, this decrease in diameter will result in a 34% increase in segmental vascular resistance, which is relatively small compared with measured changes in total pulmonary vascular resistance of 40 -60% in response to a comparable hypoxic stimulus (18,69).
Therefore, the major site of HPV is probably not located in arterioles 30 -50 m in diameter but rather in larger arterioles and arteries upstream thereof.
This, however, now poses a conceptual dilemma, as anatomic considerations render direct gas exchange between the alveolar space and pulmonary arterioles of 50 -100 m diameter unlikely.

Elaborate electron microscopic studies reveal that small precapillary pulmonary arterioles of Ͻ30 m diameter are in direct contact with the surrounding alveoli; larger arterioles, however, are enveloped by a layer of parenchyma that possesses its own net of nonalveolar capillaries and, as such, are rather remote from the alveolar space (39,72).

This arrangement therefore begs the question whether effective gas exchange and hence alveolar oxygen sensing can be achieved at the effector site of HPV, i.e., in arterioles 50 m or more in diameter.

Notably, elegant microspectrophotometric studies by Conhaim and Staub (17) identified precapillary oxygenation as rims of bright red oxygenated blood in cross sections of pulmonary arterioles of Ͼ500 m diameter in frozen cat lungs, thereby seemingly confirming that PASMC may act as both oxygen sensor and effector in HPV.

Importantly, however, Conhaim and Staub artificially maximized oxygen gradients between alveolar gas and pulmonary arterial blood in their studies by ventilating the experimental lung with air but the remainder of the lung with 10% O 2 to minimize central venous oxygen content.
Although this arrangement is ideally suited to demonstrate the principle of precapillary oxygenation even in large pulmonary arteries, it does not reflect the scenario of physiological gas exchange.

Using multispectral oximetry imaging of hemoglobin oxygen saturation at 76 different wavelengths ranging from 480 to 630 nm, we (95) recently succeeded to directly generate oxygen saturation maps of the pulmonary microvasculature in intact, ventilated mice, which allowed for the first time direct visualization of the temporal and spatial profile of pulmonary gas exchange in vivo.
Multispectral imaging confirmed the existence of precapillary oxygenation in the lung; in fact, ~50% of total oxygen uptake was found to occur before the blood enters the alveolar capillaries proper.

However, the site of this precapillary gas exchange was restricted to small arterioles Ͻ 30 m in diameter, i.e., to vascular segments which, as discussed above, do not contribute relevantly to vasoconstriction in HPV.

Hence, these findings suggest a spatial separation between the site of gas exchange and the site of vasoconstriction and hence, between the sensor and the effector of HPV, with the sensor ideally being positioned in the area of alveolocapillary gas exchange, necessitating the existence of retrograde signaling mechanisms linking it to the effector in upstream pulmonary arterioles and arteries (Fig. 2).

In the systemic microcirculation of skeletal muscles, such retrograde signal conduction from capillaries to upstream ar- terioles is a well-described mechanism by which vasoconstrictive and -dilatory signals are propagated over long distances.
Such conducted responses are initiated by local hyper-or depolarizations that spread along the vasculature via transmembrane gap junctions that are formed by connexin proteins (84).

Of these connexin 40 (Cx40), Cx37, Cx43, and possibly Cx45 are expressed in the cardiovascular system, with Cx40 being exclusively expressed by endothelial cells, whereas Cx37 and Cx43 are expressed by both endothelial and smooth muscle cells (8).

In the mouse cremaster muscle, the conduction of a vasodilatory response to electrical or pharmacological stimulation from capillaries to upstream arterioles was shown to be in particular dependent upon Cx40 (21,25).

By use of a combination of physiological measurements and real-time imaging approaches in the intact mouse lung, we had probed whether a similar conducted response may exist in the lung vascular response to hypoxia, and identified a critical role for endothelial Cx40 in that HPV could be blocked by Cx40specific and nonspecific uncouplers of gap junctional communcation in isolated perfused lungs of Cx40 ϩ/ϩ mice, or in Cx40 Ϫ/Ϫ lungs.
In vivo, Cx40 Ϫ/Ϫ mice showed more pronounced V ˙A/Q ˙mismatch in inhomogeneously ventilated lungs (102).

These finding were independently confirmed by two other groups, demonstrating that the nonspecific gap junctional uncoupler 18 ␣-glycyrrhetinic acid attenuates HPV in isolated perfused rat lungs (67) and in anesthetized rats in vivo (53), respectively.

Of note, the emerging role of gap junctions in HPV provides for an intriguing explanation for the known, and clinically often problematic, inhibitory effect of volatile anesthetics on HPV (36), as volatile anesthetics happen to be among the most potent gap junction uncouplers (42,63).

Expression of Cx40 in murine lungs is restricted to the endothelium of pulmonary arterioles, and-in notable contrast to the systemic circulation, where Cx40 is confined to arterioles (58)-alveolar capillaries (102).

The latter finding is in line with results obtained in mice which express a Cx40dependent transcriptionally controlled fluorescence protein that in the lung is restricted to endothelial cells of arterioles and capillaries, whereas venules failed to express a fluorescence signal (97).

The specific relevance of endothelial Cx40 was furthermore confirmed by experiments in lungs isolated from mice with an endothelial-specific loss of Cx40, which showed again a significant attenuation of the HPV response compared with their corresponding wild-type littermates (102).

The unique presence of Cx40 in the endothelium of both alveolar capillaries and pulmonary arterioles makes Cx40 ideally suited to mediate the spread of signals from the area of gas exchange to upstream resistance vessels, and reveals for the first time a critical role of the lung vascular endothelium in HPV that is specific for the intact lung, but not evident (since not required) in isolated pulmonary arterial rings or cultured PASMC where PASMC are directly exposed to the hypoxic stimulus.

Subsequent real-time fluorescence imaging of the endothelial membrane potential in intact lungs demonstrated that hypoxia induces a depolarization of the cell membrane in capillary endothelial cells that propagates retrogradely to the feeding arterioles in wild-type mice, yet not in mice deficient in Cx40, thus substantiating the concept of a hypoxia-triggered conducted response that is propagated retrogradely along the endothelial lining via Cx40 (102).

It is noteworthy, however, that the requirement for endothelial Cx40 does not rule out a synergistic oxygen sensing mechanism in PASMC of small pulmonary arterioles which are still within the diameter range (Ͻ30 m) of alveolar gas exchange.

Although the smooth muscle layer in these precapillary vessels is discontinuous, it is conceivable that a parallel conducted response emerges in the vascular media that is propagated upstream in parallel to the endothelial signal, and acts in conjunction with the latter to trigger HPV.
The propagation of a signal between smooth muscle cells would, however, rely on connexins other than Cx40, which is exclusive for the endothelium.

A potential candidate for such a connexin is Cx43, which is expressed in both endothelial and smooth muscle cells, and functionally contributes to HPV in a manner that is additive to the effect of Cx40, as a combination of inhibitory peptides directed against Cx40 and Cx43 had an additive inhibitory effect on HPV compared with each peptide alone (102).

Whether Cx43 provides for an alternative pathway (via either endothelial or smooth muscle cells) for a conducted response in HPV, mediates endothelial-smooth muscle cell crosstalk via myoendothelial junctions as discussed in the next section, or forms heteromeric (different connexins within one connexon hemichannel) or heterotypic (two connexons composed of different connexins forming a channel) gap junctions with Cx40 is presently not clear.

div.head: Endothelial-Smooth Muscle Cell Crosstalk in Hypoxic Pulmonary Vasoconstriction

p.s: The recognition of a critical role for the endothelium in HPV, however, immediately raises a new conceptual question: How does the endothelial depolarization that is propagated upstream via gap junctions as a conducted response ultimately evoke contraction of the adjoining smooth muscle cells?

Contraction of PASMC is triggered via an increase in the cytosolic Ca 2ϩ concentration ([Ca 2ϩ ] i ) and a concomitant activation of Rho kinase (RhoK) by RhoA GTPase (91), which act conjointly in that Ca 2ϩ /calmodulin signaling activates myosin light chain kinase, while RhoA/RhoK signaling inhibits myosin light chain phosphatase, to the effect that both synergistically promote actomyosin interaction (91).

Studies by Sylvester, Shimoda, and coworkers revealed Ca 2ϩ influx through non-selective cation channels as essential mechanism for the hypoxia-induced Ca 2ϩ response in PASMC (104) and subsequently narrowed the potential candidates down to the canonical transient receptor potential channels (TRPC) 1, 4, or 6 (101).

In their landmark study in 2006, Weissmann, Dietrich, and colleagues (105) consequently identified TRPC6 as the critical TRPC channel in the PASMC [Ca 2ϩ ] i response, in that acute HPV and the concurrent [Ca 2ϩ ] i increase are ablated in TRPC6-deficient mice and PASMC, respectively.

Hypoxia induces translocation of TRPC6 to caveolin-rich lipid rafts (52) and concomitant formation of the TRPC6 activator diacylglycerol (DAG) (105), and HPV is prevented when DAG synthesis is blocked by inhibition of phospholipase C (PLC) (32).
Hence, the hypoxia-induced, endothelial-derived signal that triggers PASMC contraction would need to stimulate translocation of TRPC6 while concomitantly activating PLC and RhoK.
As we will discuss in the following sections, these requirements are met in the pulmonary circulation by a family of fast and locally acting intercellular mediators of the sphingolipid family.
Myoendothelial junctions.

Following up on the concept of a conducted response, it is tempting to speculate that a similar electrical conduction mechanism may propagate the signal even further, i.e., directly to the vascular smooth muscle cells.

Such conduction exists in the systemic circulation in the form of myoendothelial junctions, which not only allow for the spread of de-or hyperpolarization between adjoining endothelial and smooth muscle cells, but also serve as signaling microdomains to organize proteins used to facilitate vascular heterocellular communication (89).

Recent work from the laboratory of Jeremy Ward and Philip Aaronson points toward a similar mechanism in HPV, as they were able to demonstrate a requirement for gap junctional communication in isolated pulmonary arterial rings mounted on a myograph using a variety of pharmacological gap junction uncouplers (53).

Since in isolated pulmonary arterial rings the role of gap junctions cannot be attributed to longitudinal conduction of an endothelial signal, this finding may point toward a functional role of myoendothelial junctions in HPV.

Indeed, the existence of myoendothelial junctions in small pulmonary arteries has been documented at both the anatomic (20) and functional level (9), and gap junctional uncoupling was associated with a reduced hypoxia-induced phosphorylation of the Rho kinase target MYPT-1, indicating that this pathway causes Ca 2ϩ sensitization in PASMC (53).

However, given the fact that cultured PASMC per se are capable of contracting in hypoxia and that endothelial denudation does not attenuate HPV in isolated pulmonary arteries (as discussed above), the necessity for myoendothelial junctions in the myograph setting remains not fully resolved.
Gaseous mediators.

Apart from direct connection via myoendothelial junctions, endothelial release of vasoconstrictive mediators that act in a temporally and spatially tightly controlled manner presents the obvious alternative scenario how the endothelium may trigger PASMC contraction in response to hypoxia in the intact lung.

Given the short time course of the response, de novo synthesis of a proteinaceous mediator can be effectively excluded; yet, gaseous or lipid mediators would seem ideally suited based on their rapid yet transient production, high diffusibility, rapid effects in recipient cells, and short half-life (74).

A series of studies have probed for a potential role of nitric oxide (NO) in HPV and demonstrated its important modulatory role in that excess production of NO has been linked to impaired HPV in some scenarios (as will be discussed below), whereas conversely, inhibition of endogenous NO production augments the HPV response (35).

As endogenous NO production decreases with hypoxia (55), this reduction in NO may act as an enhancer of HPV, in line with the finding that the nonspecific NO synthase inhibitor L-NAME increases hypoxic pulmonary artery pressure in isolated perfused rabbit lungs (99).

That notwithstanding, changes in NO production do not seem to play a key role in the basic sensory and signaling mechanism that elicits the physiological HPV response per se (40) which is in agreement with the finding that in the majority of species, inhibition of NO synthesis does not increase tension in isolated pulmonary artery rings, or pulmonary artery pressure in isolated lungs or in vivo preparations, respectively (41).
Similar to NO, carbon monoxide (CO) inhibits rather than triggers HPV (108), although it has recently also been shown to rescue an intact HPV response in endotoxemic mice (49).

Of most promise in the context of HPV is probably the third gaseous mediator, hydrogen sulfide (H 2 S), as H 2 S, similar to hypoxia, causes vasodilation in systemic, yet vasoconstriction in pulmonary arteries (70).
In isolated rat pulmonary arteries, the H 2 S precursor cysteine or the sulfide precursor 3-mercaptopyruvate both enhance HPV (78,79).

Conversely, blockade of H 2 S synthesis by inhibition of either cystathionine ␥-lyase or 3-mercaptopyruvate sulfur transferase reduces the increase in pulmonary arterial pressure during hypoxia in the isolated, perfused rat lung preparation (60).
These findings point toward a potentially important role of H 2 S in HPV, yet the exact signaling events upstream and downstream of H 2 S in this scenario remain to be elucidated.
Arachidonic acid metabolites.

On the lipid side, various arachidonic acid metabolites have been tested for their potential implication in HPV based on the fact that pharmacological inhibition (102) or genetic deletion (47) of cytosolic phospholipase A 2 inhibits pulmonary vasoconstriction in response to hypoxia.

In the majority of studies, however, the observed changes in these metabolites in response to acute hypoxia would favor vasodilatory rather than vasoconstrictive responses, in that prostacyclin (PGI 2 ) typically increased, while thomboxanes decreased (91), rendering them unlikely mediators of HPV.
A notable exception are epoxyeicosatrienoic acids (EETs), arachidonic acid metabolites that in the vasculature are formed by cytochrome P-450 (CYP) enzymes, specifically by CYP2C and CYP2J.

Similar to hypoxia, the regioisomers 5,6-, 8,9-, 11,12-, and 14,15-EET act as potent endothelium-derived vasoconstrictors in the pulmonary circulation (51,113), while causing vasorelaxation in systemic blood vessels (28).
CYPs are expressed at high levels in pulmonary tissue (46), with a particular abundance of CYP2J in human pulmonary endothelium (111).

EETs have been mechanistically implicated in HPV, in that 1) their levels have been found to increase in response to hypoxia in isolated murine lungs; 2) pharmacological inhibition of CYP blocks while inhibition of EETs metabolism by soluble epoxyhydrolase amplifies HPV; and 3) EETs trigger translocation of TRPC6 channels to caveolae of PASMC, a characteristic effect of hypoxia in PASMC and a requirement for an intact HPV response (51,76).

Moreover, EETs formation in lung endothelial cells could be linked to the conducted response in HPV, in that the propagating endothelial depolarization was found to activate voltage-gated, ␣ 1G -subtype T-type Ca 2ϩ channels, with the resulting Ca 2ϩ influx triggering translocation and activation of cytosolic phospholipase A 2 , ultimately resulting in the formation of EETs (102).

Notably, EETs formation may in turn modulate endothelial signal conduction in HPV in a biphasic feed-backward loop characterized by a temporary rise in electrical coupling between endothelial cells that is followed by a longer uncoupling (77), a pattern that matches the time course of the pulmonary vasoconstriction response to hypoxia with an initial peak that is followed by a decline.

Yet, although EETs clearly play an important role in HPV, they presumably do not form the signaling bridge between vascular endothelium and smooth muscle cells: albeit EETs were initially considered to regulate vascular tone by serving as direct intercellular mediators, they act primarily intracellularly and trigger downstream responses which in turn communicate signals from the endothelium to the adjacent smooth muscle layer (11).
Sphingolipids.
Apart from arachidonic acid metabolites, sphingolipids have emerged of late as important mediators of lung vascular responses to acute and chronic hypoxia (13,15).

Specifically, pharmacological inhibition of neutral sphingomyelinase (NSMase) was found to inhibit HPV both in isolated perfused mouse lungs and in anesthetized open-chest rats, whereas exogenous NSMase causes vasoconstriction in isolated lungs and contraction of cultured PASMC, respectively (14,93).
Upon activation, SMases synthesize ceramide from membrane sphingomyelin (15, 110) (Fig. 3).

There is so far no known receptor for ceramide; however, ceramide activates a series of downstream signaling pathways by formation of ceramide-rich membrane platforms which cluster receptor molecules and recruit intracellular signaling molecules (38), including the translocation of TRPC6 to caveolae (83).
Ceramidase converts ceramide to sphingosine, while ceramide synthase facilitates the reverse reaction.
Phosphorylation of sphingosine by sphingosine kinases (SphKs) yields the signaling molecule sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P).

S1P may trigger cellular responses by two different principles: On the one hand, S1P acts as an intracellular signaling molecule by mechanisms that are poorly understood but likely similar to those of ceramide in that S1P regulates the formation and composition of lipid rafts (29).

On the other hand, S1P signals as an extracellular mediator via five cell surface G protein-coupled receptors termed S1P 1-5 , of which S1P 1-3 (19) and recently also S1P 4 (71) have been found expressed in the vasculature.
The biological action of S1P is terminated by its degradation by S1P lyase, or by dephosphorylation back to sphingosine.
Hypoxia triggers rapid (Ͻ3 min) formation of ceramide in isolated PASMC (15), and elevated levels of S1P have been detected in pulmonary arteries from rodents exposed to chronic hypoxia (13).

Both sphingolipids, S1P and ceramide, seem to be critically involved in HPV: A role for S1P can be deduced from the findings that 1) inhibition or deficiency of SphK as well as 2) pharmacological blockade of the S1P receptors S1P 2 and S1P 4 attenuate HPV (93), while exogenous S1P induces vasoconstriction in isolated pulmonary arterial vessel segments (Fig. 4) and isolated perfused lungs via these receptors (71,96).

The downstream effects of this S1P receptor activation appear to be at least twofold: On the one hand, S1P 2 (via G␣ q/11 ) (45, 112) and S1P 4 (via G␣ i ) (34) activate phospholipase C, which catalyzes the conversion of phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP 2 ) into inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP 3 ) and diacylglycerol (DAG), the classical activator of TRPC6 (22).

Both, S1P 2 and S1P 4 also signal via G␣ 12/13 to activate RhoA (33,92), which in turn facilitates translocation of TRPC6 to caveolae in a mechanism dependent on phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) (53).

Importantly, the role of SphK1, the main source of S1P formation outside the nucleus, and S1P can be mechanistically linked to the endothelial conducted response, in that lung endothelial cells express high levels of SphK1 that markedly exceed those of PASMC (50), that SphK1 translocates upon activation in a Ca 2ϩ -dependent manner to lipid rafts where it binds to the inner leaflet of the plasma membrane (31,75), and that SphK1 activity is amplified by EETs with a time constant that matches the HPV response (43).

As for ceramide, work by the group of Perez-Vizcaino identified a signaling pathway that involves protein kinase C (PKC) -dependent inhibition of voltage-dependent K v potassium channels and subsequent activation of voltage-gated Ltype Ca 2ϩ channels by the resulting depolarization (15), as well as NSMase-and PKC -dependent phosphorylation of the p47 phox subunit of NAD(P)H oxidase, and consequential production of reactive oxygen species (30).
Ceramide has also been found to activate Rho kinase in cardiac myocytes (12), yet a similar effect in PASMC remains to be shown.
Finally, ceramide mediates the translocation of TRPC6 to caveolae in pulmonary endothelial cells upon stimulation with plateletactivating factor (83).
A similar effect could be shown for PASMC, and linked to HPV, in that acute hypoxia stimulated caveolar recruitment of TRPC6 that was blocked by inhibition of NSMase, but not by SphK1 blockers (93).

Unexpectedly, hypoxia-induced and ceramide-dependent recruitment of TRPC6 to caveolae was found to be also dependent upon the Cl Ϫ channel and ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) (93).

CFTR can interact directly with TRPC6 (1), and this interaction is stimulated by hypoxia in PASMC yet blocked by pharmacological inhibition of CFTR which in turn prevents TRPC6 recruitment to caveolae (93).

As a consequence, pharmacological inhibition or genetic deletion of CFTR results in an impaired HPV response (93), providing for an intriguing mechanistic explanation for the well-documented impairment in V ˙A/Q ˙matching in cystic fibrosis patients, beyond that arising from the structural damage to airways and parenchyma that occurs with this disease.

div.head: Hypoxic Pulmonary Vasoconstriction in Infection and Inflammation

p.s: V ˙A/Q ˙mismatching presents a major challenge in critically ill patients as HPV becomes impaired in local or systemic disease states associated with infection and/or inflammation such as bacterial sepsis (27), endotoxemia (37,80), or pneumonia (64).
Although a series of studies have aimed to identify the pathophysiological events that underlie this effect, no conclusive mechanism has emerged as of yet, and the clinical problem persists (23).
Considerable attention has been given to the hypothesis that increased formation of NO from inducible NO synthase (NOS2) may counteract HPV in inflammatory conditions.

In support of this view, NOS2 inhibition was found to restore HPV, increase oxygenation, and decrease shunt fraction in ovine models of ARDS or endotoxemia (24,69), in a rat sepsis model of cecal ligation and puncture (26), and in murine endotoxemia, respectively (88).

In two models of inflammatory lung disease, namely hyperoxic and ventilator-induced lung injury, increased nitric oxide production was also found to parallel the inhibition of HPV (107) while NOS2 deficiency reconstituted the HPV response (56).

Conversely, however, in a recent study in endotoxemic rats the pulmonary artery pressure response to hypoxia increased similarly following inhibition of NO production by nitro-L-arginine in isolated lungs of endotoxemic and control animals (40).

Notably, in this study endotoxemic rats showed an exaggerated rather than an impaired HPV response compared with controls; the exact reasons for this obvious discrepancy remain, however, so far unclear.

Apart from NO production, the emerging signaling axis via a Cx40-mediated conducted response along the vascular endothelium and a subsequent sphingolipid-mediated and CFTRdependent crosstalk between endothelial and smooth muscle cells (Fig. 5) provides for additional conceivable (and potentially targetable) mechanisms by which infection or inflammation may attenuate HPV.
First, inflammatory disorders block gap junctional communication and thus conducted responses, which will in turn attenuate HPV in intact lungs.

In murine lungs, pulmonary inflammation caused by either nasal instillation of lipopolysaccharide (LPS) or systemic inflammation induced by cecal ligation and puncture cause a time-dependent downregulation of Cx43 and an almost complete loss of Cx40 over 24 h (81).

In addition, LPS modulates Cx40 function via an ERK1/2-, PKA-, and PKC-dependent signaling pathway (10) resulting in reduced, Cx40-dependent electrical coupling between microvascular endothelial cells (86).

As loss of gap junctional communication may therefore play an important role in impaired HPV, the recent surge for gap junctional enhancers for the treatment of atrial fibrillation (85) may provide for a novel, yet so far untested strategy to improve V ˙A/Q ˙matching in critically ill patients with infectious or inflammatory lung and/or systemic disease syndromes.

Reconstitution of gap junctional communication may also explain the fact that 4-aminopyridine, a blocker of voltage-gated K v channels, can rescue HPV in endotoxemic mice (87), a finding that seems counterintuitive at first given the documented role of K v channels in HPV (2,68), but that suddenly makes sense in view of the fact that 4-aminopyridine can also restore gap junctional communication by a so-far unresolved mechanism (73).
Downstream of gap junctional communication, formation of EETs may Fig. 4. Sphingosine-1-phosphate causes vasoconstriction in pulmonary arteries.

Group data show dose-response curves for vascular tone in isolated, cannulated, and pressurized murine pulmonary arterial vessel segments of ~200-m outer diameter and ~1-mm length in response to sphingosine-1phosphate (black circles) and phenylephrine (white circles), which served as positive control.

equally present a suitable target for restoration of V ˙A/Q ˙matching in inflammatory lung disease, as recently demonstrated by Wepler and colleagues (106) who were able to rescue HPV and increase systemic arterial oxygenation in endotoxemic mice in vivo by pharmacological inhibition or genetic deficiency of soluble epoxyhydrolase.

Last but not least, the implication of CFTR in HPV presents a third tentative mechanism for V ˙A/Q ˙mismatch, in that loss of CFTR protein expression and short circuit current is a characteristic response to viral or bacterial infections (57,98) or stimulation with proinflammatory cytokines such as tumor necrosis factor-␣, transforming growth factor-␤, or interleukin-8 (44,65,82), resulting in functional phenocopying of cystic fibrosis disease.

This is particularly evident in cases of pulmonary or systemic infections with Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which characteristically impair HPV (27,64), as in particular nonmucoid strains of Pseudomonas aeruginosa express and secrete a virulence factor (CFTR inhibitory factor, Cif) that reduces the abundance of CFTR in the apical cell membrane (4,59).

Of interest, based on sequence similarity Cif appears to be also an epoxide hydrolase (3), a notion that is validated by enzymatic analyses confirming that Cif catalyzes the hydrolysis of epoxide compounds (4).
Thus Cif may impair HPV through a dual mechanism, in that it promotes EETs degradation and in parallel inhibits CFTR function at the cell membrane.
Accordingly, addition of exogenous Cif (kindly provided by Dean Madden, Dartmouth Medical School, New Fig. 6.
Effect of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator inhibitory factor (Cif) on hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction.

Cif was isolated from Pseudomonas aeruginosa, added to the perfusate of isolated murine lungs at a concentration of 100 g/ml, and the change in perfusion pressure (⌬PAP) in response to a switch from normoxia (21% O2) to hypoxia (1% O2) was recorded (white circles).
*P Ͻ 0.05 vs. control (black circles).
Fig. 5. Schematic concept for endothelial-smooth muscle cell crosstalk in hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction.

The scheme encompasses the proposed signaling events from the level of the alveolocapillary unit where alveolar hypoxia causes endothelial depolarization (Em 1) that is retrogradely propagated as a conducted response to the level of the upstream arterioles, where endothelial Ca 2ϩ signaling and formation of epoxyeicosatrienoic acids (EETs) from cytosolic phospholipase A2 (cPLA2) stimulate generation of the sphingolipid mediators ceramide and sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P) by neutral sphingomyelinase (NSMase) and sphingosine kinase 1 (SphK1).

Ceramide mediates the translocation of transient receptor potential canonical 6 (TRPC6) Ca 2ϩ channels into caveolae via a mechanism that requires direct interaction of TRPC6 with both cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) and phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN).

S1P stimulates contraction of pulmonary artery smooth muscle cells via a dual mechanism, in that it stimulates its G protein-coupled receptors S1P2 and/or S1P4 on the plasma membrane, causing a G␣q/11-or G␣i-mediated activation of phospholipase C (PLC) which catalyzes the conversion of phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) into inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG), the classical activator of TRPC6.

In parallel, S1P2 and/or S1P4 signaling via G␣12/13 activates RhoA/Rho kinase (RhoK), which facilitates the recruitment of PTEN (and hence, TRPC6) into caveolae, and in parallel acts synergistically with TRPC6-mediated Ca 2ϩ influx to promote vasoconstriction.
CIB1, calcium-and integrin-binding protein 1; Cx40, connexin 40; CYP2J, cytochrome P450 enzyme 2J; VGCC, voltage-gated Ca 2ϩ channel.
Hampshire) effectively attenuates HPV in the isolated perfused mouse lung preparation (Fig. 6).

In view of the putative role of impaired CFTR expression and function in V ˙A/Q ˙mismatching, the clinical introduction of CFTR correctors and potentiators may not only serve to alleviate symptoms in patients suffering from cystic fibrosis (5,16), but could potentially also provide a promising perspective for optimization of oxygenation in sepsis or pneumonia.

In summary, the recent implication of a critical role for the endothelium and endothelial-smooth muscle cell crosstalk in HPV does not only provide for a revised, integrative concept of a key physiological mechanism in the pulmonary vasculature, but is importantly also of considerable translational relevance as it identifies novel candidate structures and molecules, specifically connexins, EETs, and CFTR, that may be pharmacologically targeted to optimize V ˙A/Q ˙matching in critically ill patients.
Fig. 2. Schematic concept for the role of the endothelium in hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction.

Alveolar hypoxia is primarily sensed at the level of the alveolocapillary barrier from where the hypoxic signal is propagated retrogradely along the vascular endothelium as a conducted response via gap junctions composed of connexin 40 to the area of vasoconstriction in the upstream arterioles, and subsequently triggers contraction of adjacent pulmonary artery smooth muscle cells via endothelial-smooth muscle cell crosstalk.
Fig.3.
Key sphingolipids (black) and metabolic enzymes (blue) involved in the synthesis and degradation of ceramide and sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P).
SMase, sphingomyelinase; S1P, sphingosine-1-phosphate.
